section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to introduce the letters Uu and Vv, engage children with a dance, and introduce the vocabulary words (zoomed, screen).
Begin Story Time by introducing the book and asking: Why did Moose want to go to school?
Read for enjoyment and understanding.
Check understanding. Differentiate as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Ask and answer questions about story elements.
Identify at least 20 uppercase and 20 lowercase letters in isolation.
Understand that people use different languages to communicate and to express simple greetings and phrases in a language other than their own.
Sing, play musical instruments, and move to the rhythm in classroom activities.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Introduce children to the letters Uu and Vv.
Read aloud Look at Us! and The Visit.
Encourage children to identify the sounds /u/ and /w/.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How can we help animals stay healthy?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: What type of pet do you see in that book?
What pet can you pretend to be?
Can you name three animals that people can have as pets?
Draw a picture of a pet animal. What will you draw?
What materials will you use to make a pet? What color will your pet be?
What letter makes the sound you hear at the beginning of the word under? Can you write the letter?
Can you use blocks to build a funny pet?

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to share the Mind Builder Identify Emotions and introduce vocabulary (feelings, disliked).
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to Hello Goodbye Dog.
Read closely to notice ways the children share their feelings.
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Ask and answer questions about story elements.
Write for different purposes.
Identify emotions in others.
Understand that people use different languages to communicate and to express simple greetings in phrases in a language other than their own.
Act out to recreate and retell stories, moods, or experiences.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Help children identify emotions and discuss different emotions.
Invite them to draw pictures of Moose and have his face show different emotions.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How can we help animals stay healthy?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Can you find a pet in your book?
Can you pretend to be happy? Can you pretend to be sad?
Can you name four feelings?
Can you write about a time when you were happy?
Which pet can you make with these materials?
What letter makes the sound you hear at the beginning of the word vest? Can you write it?
Can you build a happy pet?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Hello Goodbye Dog by Maria Gianferrari, illustrated by Patrice Barton. Text copyright © 2017 by Maria Gianferrari. Illustrations copyright © 2017 by Patrice Barton. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Roaring Brook Press, an imprint of Macmillan Publishing Group LLC. Clifford the Big Red DogTM illustration copyright © The Norman Bridwell Trust.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.Photo © Aleksey Sagitov/Shutterstock.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to build background about therapy dog, play a feelings guessing game, and introduce vocabulary (check).
Begin Story Time by asking the guiding question: Why does Moose end up in therapy dog school?
Read interactively for deeper comprehension.
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Ask and answer questions about story elements.
Remove a word from a compound word.
Contribute ideas and participate in group writing.
Identify emotions in others.
Tolerate frustration as a step to learning.
Act out to recreate and retell stories, moods, or experiences.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Help children explore the different things Moose has to do to graduate from therapy school, recalling details and vocabulary from the story to help them.
Use the Activity Cards to identify training.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How can we help animals stay healthy?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: How are therapy dogs and other pets the same? How are they different?
Pretend you have a therapy dog with you. What will you do together?
How many pets can you think of that have four legs?
Can you write a story about a therapy dog?
Can you use the supplies to make a new pet for the classroom?
Find the letter at the beginning of the word up in the Magnetic Letters. Find the letter at the beginning of the word vase in the Magnetic Letters.
Can you build a therapy dog school?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Hello Goodbye Dog by Maria Gianferrari, illustrated by Patrice Barton. Text copyright © 2017 by Maria Gianferrari. Illustrations copyright © 2017 by Patrice Barton. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Roaring Brook Press, an imprint of Macmillan Publishing Group LLC.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Big Chart of Big Ideas: What Pets Need

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to talk about caring for pets and moving like pets and introduce vocabulary (pets, exercise).
Begin Story Time by connecting the texts What Pets Need and Hello Goodbye Dog.
Read closely and connect to the concept question:How can we help animals stay healthy?
Offer an extended play activity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Ask and answer questions about story elements.
Write for different purposes; Begin to experiment with end punctuation.
Identify emotions in others.
Recognize and understand how events, time, and routines relate to their lives.
Act out to recreate or retell stories, moods, or experiences.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Help children differentiate and connect concepts across two texts.
Invite children to create a simple pet out of play clay and use their pet to show different ways that people take care of animals.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How can we help animals stay healthy?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Can you find ways that people care for animals in your book?
Pretend you have a pet. Show me how you take care of it.
Which is bigger: a dog or a hamster?
Write a story about having a pet. What kind of animal is your pet? Can you put a period at the end of your story?
Can you use these supplies to make some things that would help you take care of a pet?
Can you draw things that start with the /u/ sound?
Can you build a safe home for your pet?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Hello Goodbye Dog by Maria Gianferrari, illustrated by Patrice Barton. Text copyright © 2017 by Maria Gianferrari. Illustrations copyright © 2017 by Patrice Barton. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Roaring Brook Press, an imprint of Macmillan Publishing Group LLC.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.Photo © Stephen Rees/Shutterstock.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to actively engage children with pet care scenarios to act out and introduce vocabulary (paws).
Begin Story Time by revisiting the book and asking: How does Zara take care of Moose?
Read and retell interactively for physical engagement and enjoyment.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Ask and answer questions about story elements.
Write for different purposes; Begin to experiment with end punctuation.
identify emotions in others.
Recognize and understand how events, time, and routines relate to their lives.
Understand that people use different languages to communicate and to express simple greetings and phrases in a language other than their own.
Act out to recreate and retell stories, moods, or experiences.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt: “What are the things to do to take care of a pet?”
Encourage children to experiment with punctuation.
Save children’s writing to display next week.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How can we help animals stay healthy?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: If you wrote your own book about having a pet, what you put in it?
Can you pretend to be a pet animal? What animal will you be?
How are your feet like a dog’s paws? How are they different?
Can you write a story about being a pet animal? What pet will you be?
Pretend that your pet walks with its paws all over a piece of paper after walking in paint. Use the supplies to show what would look like.
Can you find things in your station that start with the /v/ sound?
Can you build a paw that looks like pet’s paw?

Illustrations copyright © 2017 by Patrice Barton. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Roaring Brook Press, an imprint of Macmillan Publishing Group LLC.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Ask and respond to questions relevant to the text read aloud.
Name at least 20 uppercase and at least 20 lowercase letters in the language of instruction.
Be able to use language for different purposes.
Participate in classroom musical activities, including singing, playing musical instruments, and moving to the rhythm.
Ask and respond to questions relevant to the text read aloud.
Independently write to communicate ideas for a variety of purposes.
Demonstrate an understanding that others have perspectives and feelings that are different from their own.
Be able to use language for different purposes.
Create or recreate stories, moods, or experiences through dramatic representations.
Ask and respond to questions relevant to the text read aloud.
Delete a word from a compound word.
Discuss and contribute ideas for drafts composed in whole- /small-group writing activities.
Demonstrate an understanding that others have perspectives and feelings that are different from their own.

section-block.tg_skills-focus_body: Drama: Create or recreate stories, moods, or experiences through dramatic representations. (TX.VIII.C.1).

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Ask and respond to questions relevant to the text read aloud.
Independently write to communicate ideas for a variety of purposes.
Begin to experiment with punctuation when writing.
Demonstrate an understanding that others have perspectives and feelings that are different from their own
Connect their lives to events, time, and routines.
Create or recreate stories, moods, or experiences through dramatic representations.
Ask and respond to questions relevant to the text read aloud.
Independently write to communicate ideas for a variety of purposes.
Begin to experiment with punctuation when writing.
Demonstrate an understanding that others have perspectives and feelings that are different from their own.
Connect their lives to events, time, and routines.
Be able to use language for different purposes.
Create or recreate stories, moods, or experiences through dramatic expressions.
